content.question: The derivative of the function <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></math> is given by <math alttext="B prime of t, equals, 8 times e raised to the 0.2 times cosine t, power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>0.2</mn><mi>cos</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></msup></mrow></math>, and <math alttext="B of 2.2, equals 4.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>B</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>2.2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>4.5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. If the linear approximation to <math alttext="B of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>B</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="t equals 2.2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2.2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> is used to estimate <math alttext="B of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>B</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, at what value of <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> does the linear approximation estimate that <math alttext="B of t, equals 9" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>B</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

topic.text: 4.6: Approximating Values of a Function Using Local Linearity and Linearization

skill.text: Skill 1.F: Explain how an approximated value relates to the actual value.
